preposition.description: At or to the far side of (something), typically so as to be hidden by it.
examples: the recording machinery was kept behind screens
the sun came out from behind a cloud

preposition.description: In a line or procession, following or further back than (another member of the line or procession)
In support of or giving guidance to (someone else)
examples: whatever you decide to do, I'll be behind you

preposition.description: After the departure or death of (the person referred to)
examples: he left behind him a manuscript that was subsequently published

preposition.description: Less advanced than (someone else) in achievement or development.
examples: the government admitted it is ten years behind the West in PC technology

preposition.description: Having a lower score than (another competitor)
examples: Woodnam moved to ten under par, five shots behind Fred Couples

adverb.description: At or to the far side or the back side of something.
examples: as I looked behind, my feet crashed into a basket

adverb.description: Remaining after someone or something is gone.
examples: blocks of ice left behind by a retreating glacier

adverb.description: Further back than other members of a group.
examples: Bill led the way, with the others a short distance behind

adverb.description: (in a game or contest) having a score lower than that of the opposition.
examples: polls showed him as much as 50 points behind

adverb.description: Slow or late in accomplishing a task.
In a place or time already past.

noun.description: A one-point score made by kicking the ball between the outer set of two sets of goalposts (the behind line), or by touching the ball, causing it to pass between the inner posts (goalposts).

origin: Old English behindan, bihindan, from bi by + hindan from behind.
